Triggering Event: A female journalist, aged 20 and married, is tasked with covering a local council meeting for her newspaper. Despite arriving early and setting up her equipment, she finds herself repeatedly ignored by the mayor who only acknowledges male reporters present. As the meeting progresses, she becomes increasingly frustrated as he continually takes questions from them while hers go unanswered.

He's taking questions from other men who are just sitting there, yet I've been standing here for 10 minutes waiting for him to acknowledge me." **Mayor:** "Sorry, ma'am, we're just moving through the agenda. Please wait your turn." **Journalist:** "Wait my turn? It's been an hour since I arrived! Meanwhile, those men have already asked three questions, and you haven't even noticed me. This is unacceptable." **Councilor:** "Ma'am, please allow us to finish our discussion before—" **Journalist:** "Discussion? You call this a discussion? We're wasting time! The public has a right to know what's happening in these meetings. I don’t want to be at a press conference; I want to report live from this very room! Triggering Event: A patient, unaware of her phobia for bodily fluids, suddenly vomited while she was checking his IV drip. The sight and sound triggered an instant wave of disgust, making her stomach churn and face pale. She stepped back hastily, dropping her clipboard in surprise.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, this is so embarrassing. I'm such a freak—can't handle even a little blood or sweat. Seeing that IV drip just made me sick to my stomach. It's like I can't control it; I feel nauseous just thinking about it. I'm seriously going to need some Tums after this one."

Triggering Event: A retired teacher, now in his late sixties, watches from his kitchen window as his former student, now a successful author, arrives home next door with another box of books inscribed with personal notes from admirers. He notices the student's smile, contentment etched deep into their wrinkles, mirroring none of his own.

No, I don't want to talk about him right now.** He's got it all together now. **Smiling, walking up to his house, carrying boxes... like he owns the place. It makes me sick.** **It doesn't help that I'm still living in this tiny apartment, and he has this huge house. My life is just so much smaller than his. I feel like I'm wasting my time trying to make ends meet. And what's worse, I can't even enjoy it because I have to worry about bills all the time.** **And then there's this new book he's written. All these people are raving about it, saying how great a job he did. Meanwhile, I've been struggling to finish my own writing project for years. It's almost as if they're ignoring me completely.** But you know what really gets under my skin? The fact that he looks happy. Happy! He's got his life together, while mine is falling apart. It's just not fair. I try to tell myself that everyone has their own struggles, but it's hard when everything feels like it's going downhill for me. I've tried to get back into writing, but it's just not the same. Maybe I'm just jealous of his success? Yeah, maybe. But why does it always seem to come so easily for some people? Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She's walking home from the lab, her footsteps echoing through the empty streets. A faint rustling in the bushes behind her sends a chill down her spine. She quickens her pace, clutching her bag tighter. The rustling persists, growing louder. She dares not look back, fearing what she might see. Reaching her apartment door, she fumbles with her keys, heart pounding. As she finally slips inside and locks the door behind her, she swears she hears a soft tapping at her window.
Generated Assessment: **Oh, you're really paranoid today aren't you?** You think someone is trying to break into your house because... **you heard some leaves rustle outside?** That doesn't sound like a typical squirrel move. And now you're freaking out about it, huh? **It's probably just a stray cat looking for scraps. You've been working late again, so maybe it's time to get some fresh air and feed that poor thing instead of locking yourself in.** Your mind is playing tricks on you again, isn't it? It's always something. Maybe you should take a deep breath, grab a glass of water, and let go of those anxious thoughts. Your cat friend will still be there when you come back to reality. Don't worry; this too shall pass. Just relax and enjoy the evening. No need to overthink everything. After all, it's just a little noise.

Triggering Event: Walking his beat, he noticed the small, familiar blue house at the end of Maple Street. It was quiet, unlike the last time he'd been there for Mrs. Thompson's 91st birthday party, filled with laughter and cake. Today, it stood silent, a fresh 'For Sale' sign planted in the yard. He paused, swallowing hard as grief welled up again, raw and unexpected. The house was a reminder of happier times, now tarnished by Mrs. Thompson's sudden passing last week. His radio crackled to life, breaking the moment, but the memory lingered, heavy and unyielding.
Generated Assessment: As I walked past the house that once brought me joy, I couldn't help but feel a sense of betrayal. The "For Sale" sign seemed like an ominous warning, a harbinger of change that threatened to erase the memories we had created within its walls. Why would anyone want to disturb the tranquility of such a beautiful place? The thought sent a shiver down my spine, and I felt the urge to push open the creaky front door, as if searching for answers. But the silence inside only deepened the mystery, leaving me with more questions than when I began. My mind raced with possibilities—perhaps the new owners would rip out the old oak tree, destroying the very essence of our neighborhood. Or maybe they wouldn't even care about preserving the history that surrounded them. The idea alone made my blood boil, and I found myself wondering if I could somehow stop this transformation. But the reality was clear: nothing could prevent the inevitable. With each step, I felt the weight of loss growing heavier, until the pain became almost unbearable. If only I could turn back time, I would have cherished every moment, cherished every laugh, and cherished every tear. Now, all I can do is stand here, frozen in grief, as the world around me continues to move forward. The once-peaceful street now echoes with the sound of hammers and saws, a stark reminder that some things cannot be stopped. Yet, despite the inevitability of change, I

Triggering Event: A sudden power outage in his quiet apartment, plunging him into darkness while he was preparing a complex recipe from memory. The gas burner's flame had flickered ominously moments before the lights went out, leaving him gripping the countertop, heart pounding, as he strained to hear any unusual noises from outside his door.
Generated Assessment: I feel like this is supposed to happen. Like, it makes sense. It should have been the case. But no, instead I'm left here with nothing but the faint scent of cooking oil wafting up through the vents and the eerie silence of an unlit world outside. Why would anyone else get to experience what they want when I can't? The kitchen is dark, and so am I. What kind of sick joke is this? It shouldn't be like this. It's just how things go sometimes. Not for me. I don't know why, but it feels wrong, like I've somehow missed the mark. I should have done something differently. Shouldn't I have noticed the gas burner sooner? It wasn't supposed to fail now; it was meant to work perfectly until then. Now, I'm stuck here, unable to even light the stove, let alone finish dinner. This isn't how things are supposed to go. It shouldn't end like this. I should have been able to handle it better. Maybe if I'd been more prepared, if I'd paid closer attention, none of this would have happened. But no, it did anyway, and now I'm left dealing with the consequences, all because I didn't "do" enough. And now, everything is ruined—my plans, my appetite, my whole mood. This isn't right. It shouldn't be like this. It's not fair. I can't believe this is happening.

Triggering Event: She woke up to an empty apartment, the silence punctuated only by the ticking of her vintage alarm clock. Her cat, who usually greeted her with soft meows, was nowhere to be found. She remembered he'd been hit by a car last week, and the vet's words echoed in her mind: "It was quick, but it was still a loss." Tears welled up as she reached for her coffee mug, knocking it over instead. The brown liquid spread across her worn wooden table, staining the newspaper clippings she'd saved from her career as a journalist - a reminder of happier times, now marred by sadness.
Generated Assessment: She had no idea what happened to her cat. He wasn't there when she got home, and the neighbors hadn't seen him since yesterday morning. It seemed like such a small thing at first, but as she sat down to make breakfast, the emptiness hit her hard. All this time, she thought they were just sleeping, but it turns out he was gone. The vet said it was too late, but she couldn't help feeling guilty for leaving him alone for so long. She remembers how much she loved him, how he'd curl up next to her at night, purring softly as she read her stories. Now his favorite spot is empty, and every sound makes her feel worse.

Triggering Event: "After meticulously preparing for their weekly discussion, Sarah's partner cancels at the last minute, stating 'I'm just not in the mood tonight.'"
Generated Assessment: You fucking idiot! I was so excited about our date tonight. You promised me all week that you'd be there, and now you're canceling because you don't feel like it? Are you kidding me?! This is the third time this month you've canceled on me at the last second. Do you even care about my feelings? How can you be so careless with your word commitments? I put a lot of effort into planning our dates, and you just keep blowing them off whenever you feel like it. It's really annoying and hurts my feelings. I thought we had something special, but clearly, I was wrong. You never respect my time or show appreciation for my efforts. If you can't make an effort to show up when you say you will, then maybe you shouldn't have agreed to go out in the first place.

Triggering Event: He sat alone in his cluttered home office, the hum of his old desktop the only sound breaking the evening's silence. His partner had left hours ago for a late dinner with colleagues, their goodbye kiss lingering like an echo in his mind. He picked up the framed photo on his desk - a younger version of them, grinning at a beachside café. Today was their anniversary, but they'd missed it amidst deadlines and schedules. A wave of sadness washed over him as he placed the frame back, its glass reflecting his own tired eyes staring back.
Generated Assessment: Oh great, another day stuck in this cramped space, surrounded by papers and screens that never seem to end. The world outside is moving, yet I'm still here, drowning in my own thoughts. It's been years since we met, but what does that even mean? We're just two people trying to make it work, aren't we? He looks so lost in thought, completely absorbed in those photos. Maybe he wishes things were different, maybe he’s thinking about how much time has passed since our first date. Whatever it is, it feels like there’s nothing he can do to change it. That's what happens when you spend too long buried under your worries; you lose sight of what really matters. I wonder if he even knows what he wants anymore. Is he truly happy? Does he ever think about me? It’s easy to forget someone when life gets busy. But deep down, doesn’t everyone feel lonely sometimes? Even if he doesn’t admit it, I bet he misses us too. Who wouldn’t? This guy must be going crazy, sitting here all day with no one to talk to. Maybe he thinks about our fights and how he ended up alone again. Poor bastard. If anyone deserves some love, it’s him. I hope he realizes what he has before it slips away forever.
